working.current_chapter_text:
CHAPTER XXVIII

Prince Andrew was to leave next evening. The old prince, not altering
his routine, retired as usual after dinner. The little princess was in
her sister-in-law’s room. Prince Andrew in a traveling coat without
epaulettes had been packing with his valet in the rooms assigned to him.
After inspecting the carriage himself and seeing the trunks put in, he
ordered the horses to be harnessed. Only those things he always kept
with him remained in his room; a small box, a large canteen fitted
with silver plate, two Turkish pistols and a saber—a present from
his father who had brought it from the siege of Ochákov. All these
traveling effects of Prince Andrew’s were in very good order: new,
clean, and in cloth covers carefully tied with tapes.

When starting on a journey or changing their mode of life, men capable
of reflection are generally in a serious frame of mind. At such moments
one reviews the past and plans for the future. Prince Andrew’s face
looked very thoughtful and tender. With his hands behind him he paced
briskly from corner to corner of the room, looking straight before him
and thoughtfully shaking his head. Did he fear going to the war, or was
he sad at leaving his wife?—perhaps both, but evidently he did not
wish to be seen in that mood, for hearing footsteps in the passage he
hurriedly unclasped his hands, stopped at a table as if tying the
cover of the small box, and assumed his usual tranquil and impenetrable
expression. It was the heavy tread of Princess Mary that he heard.

“I hear you have given orders to harness,” she cried, panting (she
had apparently been running), “and I did so wish to have another talk
with you alone! God knows how long we may again be parted. You are not
angry with me for coming? You have changed so, Andrúsha,” she added,
as if to explain such a question.

She smiled as she uttered his pet name, “Andrúsha.” It was
obviously strange to her to think that this stern handsome man should be
Andrúsha—the slender mischievous boy who had been her playfellow in
childhood.

“And where is Lise?” he asked, answering her question only by a
smile.

“She was so tired that she has fallen asleep on the sofa in my room.
Oh, Andrew! What a treasure of a wife you have,” said she, sitting
down on the sofa, facing her brother. “She is quite a child: such a
dear, merry child. I have grown so fond of her.”

Prince Andrew was silent, but the princess noticed the ironical and
contemptuous look that showed itself on his face.

“One must be indulgent to little weaknesses; who is free from them,
Andrew? Don’t forget that she has grown up and been educated in
society, and so her position now is not a rosy one. We should enter into
everyone’s situation. Tout comprendre, c’est tout pardonner. * Think
what it must be for her, poor thing, after what she has been used to,
to be parted from her husband and be left alone in the country, in her
condition! It’s very hard.”

     * To understand all is to forgive all.

Prince Andrew smiled as he looked at his sister, as we smile at those we
think we thoroughly understand.

“You live in the country and don’t think the life terrible,” he
replied.

“I... that’s different. Why speak of me? I don’t want any other
life, and can’t, for I know no other. But think, Andrew: for a young
society woman to be buried in the country during the best years of her
life, all alone—for Papa is always busy, and I... well, you know what
poor resources I have for entertaining a woman used to the best society.
There is only Mademoiselle Bourienne....”

“I don’t like your Mademoiselle Bourienne at all,” said Prince
Andrew.

“No? She is very nice and kind and, above all, she’s much to be
pitied. She has no one, no one. To tell the truth, I don’t need her,
and she’s even in my way. You know I always was a savage, and now am
even more so. I like being alone.... Father likes her very much. She and
Michael Ivánovich are the two people to whom he is always gentle and
kind, because he has been a benefactor to them both. As Sterne says:
‘We don’t love people so much for the good they have done us, as
for the good we have done them.’ Father took her when she was homeless
after losing her own father. She is very good-natured, and my father
likes her way of reading. She reads to him in the evenings and reads
splendidly.”

“To be quite frank, Mary, I expect Father’s character sometimes
makes things trying for you, doesn’t it?” Prince Andrew asked
suddenly.

Princess Mary was first surprised and then aghast at this question.

“For me? For me?... Trying for me!...” said she.

“He always was rather harsh; and now I should think he’s getting
very trying,” said Prince Andrew, apparently speaking lightly of their
father in order to puzzle or test his sister.

“You are good in every way, Andrew, but you have a kind of
intellectual pride,” said the princess, following the train of her own
thoughts rather than the trend of the conversation—“and that’s a
great sin. How can one judge Father? But even if one might, what feeling
except veneration could such a man as my father evoke? And I am so
contented and happy with him. I only wish you were all as happy as I
am.”

Her brother shook his head incredulously.

“The only thing that is hard for me... I will tell you the truth,
Andrew... is Father’s way of treating religious subjects. I don’t
understand how a man of his immense intellect can fail to see what is
as clear as day, and can go so far astray. That is the only thing
that makes me unhappy. But even in this I can see lately a shade of
improvement. His satire has been less bitter of late, and there was a
monk he received and had a long talk with.”

“Ah! my dear, I am afraid you and your monk are wasting your
powder,” said Prince Andrew banteringly yet tenderly.

“Ah! mon ami, I only pray, and hope that God will hear me.
Andrew...” she said timidly after a moment’s silence, “I have a
great favor to ask of you.”

“What is it, dear?”

“No—promise that you will not refuse! It will give you no trouble
and is nothing unworthy of you, but it will comfort me. Promise,
Andrúsha!...” said she, putting her hand in her reticule but not yet
taking out what she was holding inside it, as if what she held were
the subject of her request and must not be shown before the request was
granted.

She looked timidly at her brother.

“Even if it were a great deal of trouble...” answered Prince Andrew,
as if guessing what it was about.

“Think what you please! I know you are just like Father. Think as
you please, but do this for my sake! Please do! Father’s father, our
grandfather, wore it in all his wars.” (She still did not take out
what she was holding in her reticule.) “So you promise?”

“Of course. What is it?”

“Andrew, I bless you with this icon and you must promise me you will
never take it off. Do you promise?”

“If it does not weigh a hundredweight and won’t break my neck...
To please you...” said Prince Andrew. But immediately, noticing
the pained expression his joke had brought to his sister’s face, he
repented and added: “I am glad; really, dear, I am very glad.”

“Against your will He will save and have mercy on you and bring you
to Himself, for in Him alone is truth and peace,” said she in a voice
trembling with emotion, solemnly holding up in both hands before her
brother a small, oval, antique, dark-faced icon of the Saviour in a gold
setting, on a finely wrought silver chain.

She crossed herself, kissed the icon, and handed it to Andrew.

“Please, Andrew, for my sake!...”

Rays of gentle light shone from her large, timid eyes. Those eyes lit
up the whole of her thin, sickly face and made it beautiful. Her brother
would have taken the icon, but she stopped him. Andrew understood,
crossed himself and kissed the icon. There was a look of tenderness, for
he was touched, but also a gleam of irony on his face.

“Thank you, my dear.” She kissed him on the forehead and sat down
again on the sofa. They were silent for a while.

“As I was saying to you, Andrew, be kind and generous as you always
used to be. Don’t judge Lise harshly,” she began. “She is so
sweet, so good-natured, and her position now is a very hard one.”

“I do not think I have complained of my wife to you, Másha, or blamed
her. Why do you say all this to me?”

Red patches appeared on Princess Mary’s face and she was silent as if
she felt guilty.

“I have said nothing to you, but you have already been talked to. And
I am sorry for that,” he went on.

The patches grew deeper on her forehead, neck, and cheeks. She tried to
say something but could not. Her brother had guessed right: the little
princess had been crying after dinner and had spoken of her forebodings
about her confinement, and how she dreaded it, and had complained of her
fate, her father-in-law, and her husband. After crying she had fallen
asleep. Prince Andrew felt sorry for his sister.

“Know this, Másha: I can’t reproach, have not reproached, and never
shall reproach my wife with anything, and I cannot reproach myself
with anything in regard to her; and that always will be so in whatever
circumstances I may be placed. But if you want to know the truth... if
you want to know whether I am happy? No! Is she happy? No! But why this
is so I don’t know...”

As he said this he rose, went to his sister, and, stooping, kissed
her forehead. His fine eyes lit up with a thoughtful, kindly, and
unaccustomed brightness, but he was looking not at his sister but over
her head toward the darkness of the open doorway.

“Let us go to her, I must say good-by. Or—go and wake and I’ll
come in a moment. Petrúshka!” he called to his valet: “Come here,
take these away. Put this on the seat and this to the right.”

Princess Mary rose and moved to the door, then stopped and said:
“Andrew, if you had faith you would have turned to God and asked Him
to give you the love you do not feel, and your prayer would have been
answered.”

“Well, maybe!” said Prince Andrew. “Go, Másha; I’ll come
immediately.”

On the way to his sister’s room, in the passage which connected one
wing with the other, Prince Andrew met Mademoiselle Bourienne smiling
sweetly. It was the third time that day that, with an ecstatic and
artless smile, she had met him in secluded passages.

“Oh! I thought you were in your room,” she said, for some reason
blushing and dropping her eyes.

Prince Andrew looked sternly at her and an expression of anger suddenly
came over his face. He said nothing to her but looked at her forehead
and hair, without looking at her eyes, with such contempt that the
Frenchwoman blushed and went away without a word. When he reached his
sister’s room his wife was already awake and her merry voice, hurrying
one word after another, came through the open door. She was speaking as
usual in French, and as if after long self-restraint she wished to make
up for lost time.

“No, but imagine the old Countess Zúbova, with false curls and her
mouth full of false teeth, as if she were trying to cheat old age....
Ha, ha, ha! Mary!”

This very sentence about Countess Zúbova and this same laugh Prince
Andrew had already heard from his wife in the presence of others some
five times. He entered the room softly. The little princess, plump and
rosy, was sitting in an easy chair with her work in her hands, talking
incessantly, repeating Petersburg reminiscences and even phrases. Prince
Andrew came up, stroked her hair, and asked if she felt rested after
their journey. She answered him and continued her chatter.

The coach with six horses was waiting at the porch. It was an autumn
night, so dark that the coachman could not see the carriage pole.
Servants with lanterns were bustling about in the porch. The immense
house was brilliant with lights shining through its lofty windows. The
domestic serfs were crowding in the hall, waiting to bid good-by to
the young prince. The members of the household were all gathered in the
reception hall: Michael Ivánovich, Mademoiselle Bourienne, Princess
Mary, and the little princess. Prince Andrew had been called to his
father’s study as the latter wished to say good-by to him alone. All
were waiting for them to come out.

When Prince Andrew entered the study the old man in his old-age
spectacles and white dressing gown, in which he received no one but his
son, sat at the table writing. He glanced round.

“Going?” And he went on writing.

“I’ve come to say good-by.”

“Kiss me here,” and he touched his cheek: “Thanks, thanks!”

“What do you thank me for?”

“For not dilly-dallying and not hanging to a woman’s apron strings.
The Service before everything. Thanks, thanks!” And he went on
writing, so that his quill spluttered and squeaked. “If you have
anything to say, say it. These two things can be done together,” he
added.

“About my wife... I am ashamed as it is to leave her on your
hands....”

“Why talk nonsense? Say what you want.”

“When her confinement is due, send to Moscow for an accoucheur.... Let
him be here....”

The old prince stopped writing and, as if not understanding, fixed his
stern eyes on his son.

“I know that no one can help if nature does not do her work,” said
Prince Andrew, evidently confused. “I know that out of a million
cases only one goes wrong, but it is her fancy and mine. They have been
telling her things. She has had a dream and is frightened.”

“Hm... Hm...” muttered the old prince to himself, finishing what he
was writing. “I’ll do it.”

He signed with a flourish and suddenly turning to his son began to
laugh.

“It’s a bad business, eh?”

“What is bad, Father?”

“The wife!” said the old prince, briefly and significantly.

“I don’t understand!” said Prince Andrew.

“No, it can’t be helped, lad,” said the prince. “They’re
all like that; one can’t unmarry. Don’t be afraid; I won’t tell
anyone, but you know it yourself.”

He seized his son by the hand with small bony fingers, shook it, looked
straight into his son’s face with keen eyes which seemed to see
through him, and again laughed his frigid laugh.

The son sighed, thus admitting that his father had understood him. The
old man continued to fold and seal his letter, snatching up and throwing
down the wax, the seal, and the paper, with his accustomed rapidity.

“What’s to be done? She’s pretty! I will do everything. Make your
mind easy,” said he in abrupt sentences while sealing his letter.

Andrew did not speak; he was both pleased and displeased that his father
understood him. The old man got up and gave the letter to his son.

“Listen!” said he; “don’t worry about your wife: what can be
done shall be. Now listen! Give this letter to Michael Ilariónovich. *
I have written that he should make use of you in proper places and not
keep you long as an adjutant: a bad position! Tell him I remember
and like him. Write and tell me how he receives you. If he is all
right—serve him. Nicholas Bolkónski’s son need not serve under
anyone if he is in disfavor. Now come here.”

     *Kutúzov.

He spoke so rapidly that he did not finish half his words, but his son
was accustomed to understand him. He led him to the desk, raised the
lid, drew out a drawer, and took out an exercise book filled with his
bold, tall, close handwriting.

“I shall probably die before you. So remember, these are my memoirs;
hand them to the Emperor after my death. Now here is a Lombard bond
and a letter; it is a premium for the man who writes a history of
Suvórov’s wars. Send it to the Academy. Here are some jottings for
you to read when I am gone. You will find them useful.”

Andrew did not tell his father that he would no doubt live a long time
yet. He felt that he must not say it.

“I will do it all, Father,” he said.

“Well, now, good-by!” He gave his son his hand to kiss, and embraced
him. “Remember this, Prince Andrew, if they kill you it will hurt me,
your old father...” he paused unexpectedly, and then in a querulous
voice suddenly shrieked: “but if I hear that you have not behaved like
a son of Nicholas Bolkónski, I shall be ashamed!”

“You need not have said that to me, Father,” said the son with a
smile.

The old man was silent.

“I also wanted to ask you,” continued Prince Andrew, “if I’m
killed and if I have a son, do not let him be taken away from you—as I
said yesterday... let him grow up with you.... Please.”

“Not let the wife have him?” said the old man, and laughed.

They stood silent, facing one another. The old man’s sharp eyes were
fixed straight on his son’s. Something twitched in the lower part of
the old prince’s face.

“We’ve said good-by. Go!” he suddenly shouted in a loud, angry
voice, opening his door.

“What is it? What?” asked both princesses when they saw for a moment
at the door Prince Andrew and the figure of the old man in a white
dressing gown, spectacled and wigless, shouting in an angry voice.

Prince Andrew sighed and made no reply.

“Well!” he said, turning to his wife.

And this “Well!” sounded coldly ironic, as if he were saying: “Now
go through your performance.”

“Andrew, already!” said the little princess, turning pale and
looking with dismay at her husband.

He embraced her. She screamed and fell unconscious on his shoulder.

He cautiously released the shoulder she leaned on, looked into her face,
and carefully placed her in an easy chair.

“Adieu, Mary,” said he gently to his sister, taking her by the hand
and kissing her, and then he left the room with rapid steps.

The little princess lay in the armchair, Mademoiselle Bourienne chafing
her temples. Princess Mary, supporting her sister-in-law, still looked
with her beautiful eyes full of tears at the door through which Prince
Andrew had gone and made the sign of the cross in his direction. From
the study, like pistol shots, came the frequent sound of the old man
angrily blowing his nose. Hardly had Prince Andrew gone when the study
door opened quickly and the stern figure of the old man in the white
dressing gown looked out.

“Gone? That’s all right!” said he; and looking angrily at the
unconscious little princess, he shook his head reprovingly and slammed
the door.

workflow.goal: Analyze 'War and Peace' to extract characters, relationships, and significant events.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXIV
chapter_summaries.summary: In the aftermath of the religious service, the tension over Count Bezúkhov's inheritance reaches a breaking point. Anna Mikháylovna and the eldest princess, Catiche, engage in a physical struggle over an inlaid portfolio containing the Count's will. Prince Vasíli attempts to intervene but is largely ignored as the two women fight for control. The conflict is interrupted by the second princess, who announces that the Count is finally dying, allowing Anna Mikháylovna to seize the portfolio and rush into the bedroom.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXV
chapter_summaries.summary: The narrative shifts to Bald Hills, the estate of the retired General Prince Nicholas Bolkónski. The chapter establishes the rigid, disciplined routine of the household as they await the arrival of Prince Andrew and his pregnant wife. Prince Nicholas is depicted as a stern, exacting father who personally educates his daughter, Princess Mary, in mathematics to combat idleness and superstition. Mary, living in fear of her father's sharp temper, receives a letter from her friend Julie Karágina, which her father mockingly acknowledges before resuming a stressful geometry lesson.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXVI
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew and his pregnant wife, Lise, arrive at the Bolkónski estate, Bald Hills. They are greeted by the valet Tíkhon and later by Mademoiselle Bourienne and Princess Mary. The reunion is emotional for the women, who weep and embrace, while Prince Andrew remains detached and somewhat irritated by the display of emotion. Andrew confirms he is leaving for the war the following day, leaving Lise at the estate, which causes her further distress.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXVII
chapter_summaries.summary: The Bolkónski family gathers for dinner at Bald Hills. The old prince demonstrates his eccentric egalitarianism by seating his architect, Michael Ivánovich, at the table. Prince Andrew mocks his father's obsession with the family genealogy to Princess Mary, while the old prince subjects Lise to his dry, cold humor regarding her pregnancy. The conversation shifts to the war, where the old prince dismisses Napoleon as an insignificant 'Frenchy' and mocks modern military tactics, while Andrew respectfully engages his father's arguments about past generals like Suvórov.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXVIII
chapter_summaries.summary: On the eve of his departure for war, Prince Andrew prepares his belongings and reflects on his future. He is interrupted by his sister, Princess Mary, who expresses her concern for his pregnant wife, Lise, and discusses their father's difficult temperament and religious views. Andrew remains cynical about his wife and their father's behavior, while Mary defends the old prince and shares her hopes for spiritual improvement.

current_goals: Host a successful reception
Promote support for the war against Napoleon
Ensure all guests follow the protocol of greeting her aunt
Manage the social reputation of her salon

A 40-year-old maid of honor to Empress Márya Fëdorovna, characterized by her social enthusiasm and political fervor.
Introduced as a high-society hostess who uses her 'enthusiasm' as a social vocation to influence court opinion.
She is shown to be highly sensitive to social hierarchy, treating guests differently based on their status and showing visible distress when etiquette is breached.
05d36871-2501-4fad-95b8-b375384f7650.last_known_location: Anna Pávlovna's drawing room, St. Petersburg

1d1ea9ad-587d-4cc3-bbb7-d7888f42ae71.evolution_summary:
An elderly, influential courtier with a serene, flat face and a habit of speaking with indifferent irony.
Introduced as a seasoned courtier who navigates social circles with practiced indifference and refined manners.
His role as a father is introduced, showing him as part of a larger family unit within the Petersburg elite.
His pragmatic approach to social influence is highlighted, as is his susceptibility to guilt regarding past debts.
His Moscow persona is more overtly arrogant and protective of his interests compared to his behavior in Petersburg.
Vasíli has shifted from a serene courtier to a visibly stressed conspirator as the Count's death approaches.
His usual dignity is slipping into visible fear and impatience as the decisive moment of the Count's death nears.
Vasíli uses the cover of a religious service to continue his clandestine maneuvers with the eldest princess.
Vasíli's composure has completely broken down; he is now unable to control the women he was previously conspiring with.

1b3b757c-1a83-443d-9b89-b768c0804f4b.identity: The stunningly beautiful and socially poised daughter of Prince Vasíli.

The beautiful daughter of Prince Vasíli and a maid of honor.
Hélène is depicted as a masterpiece of social grace, moving with a 'victorious beauty' that commands the room's attention.

88cbe937-5f37-4903-91c1-c6821b89b5d8.evolution_summary:
The pregnant wife of Prince Bolkónski, highly charming and popular in society.
Lise is shown to be an active participant in Anna Pávlovna's social engineering, contrasting with her husband's detachment.
Lise shifts from a charming socialite to a vulnerable, frightened wife who feels abandoned by her husband's lack of pity and his 'changed' attitude.
Lise's transition to the country highlights her dependence on social stimulation and her growing dread of Andrew's departure.
Lise is visibly cowed by the old prince's presence, reacting to him with the 'fear and respect' of a courtier before the Tsar.

42367a83-661b-44d3-9912-682f58053860.evolution_summary:
Illegitimate son of Count Bezúkhov; socially awkward and observant.
Introduced as a 'stout' and 'heavily built' young man whose naturalness and lack of artifice make him a disruptive force in the rigid salon environment.
His deep admiration for Prince Andrew is revealed, showing he has a loyal and emotional nature despite his social clumsiness.
Pierre transitions from being merely socially awkward to being a source of genuine political scandal in the salon by defending Napoleon's most controversial acts.
Pierre's physical clumsiness and social ineptitude are fully displayed, yet his essential 'kindly' nature earns him a reprieve from Anna Pávlovna.
Pierre's role as an 'outsider' is emphasized as he witnesses the private dysfunction of the Bolkónski marriage, showing his inability to handle emotional confrontation.
Pierre's vulnerability is highlighted as he admits his shame over his illegitimacy and his total reliance on Andrew's perceived 'strength of will'.
Pierre demonstrates a significant lack of character by immediately breaking a solemn promise to his mentor, Andrew. His physical strength is introduced as a 'Herculean' trait that contrasts with his mental indecision.
His reputation has plummeted following the events at Anatole's, making him a subject of ridicule and pity in Moscow.
Pierre has moved from a disruptive guest in Petersburg to a social pariah in Moscow, retreating into political fantasies (imagining himself as Napoleon) while being controlled by Prince Vasíli.
Pierre makes his first social appearance in Moscow following his father's illness, immediately displaying his characteristic lack of grace.
Pierre has become almost entirely passive, allowing Anna Mikháylovna to lead him through his own father's house like a child.
Pierre remains a passive figure, more focused on observing the behavior of others than on his own emotional response to his father's death.
Pierre remains a bewildered witness to the violent greed of his relatives, following Anna Mikháylovna's lead without fully grasping the stakes.

c7478c00-c2c0-46cb-8888-b9a0fc8bc2d9.description: A man with a scheme for perpetual peace.

4c270c64-9fbc-4702-aef6-76da440daf4e.evolution_summary:
A disillusioned aristocrat and husband to Lise Bolkónskaya, departing for the war against Napoleon.
Introduced as a man deeply bored by his social environment and his wife, seeking purpose in military service.
Andrew shows a willingness to support Pierre's unpopular views, highlighting his disdain for the superficiality of the other guests.
Andrew's duality is shown: he is cold and 'disagreeable' to Hippolyte but 'gentle and affectionate' toward Pierre.
Andrew's boredom with society is revealed to extend to his marriage; he treats his wife with a coldness that borders on cruelty, prioritizing his military ambitions over her emotional needs.
Andrew reveals a hidden layer of 'morbid irritation' and intense regret regarding his marriage, contrasting with his usual lifeless social mask.
Andrew returns to the rigid environment of his youth, showing he still respects his father's discipline while remaining alienated from his wife's emotional needs.
Andrew shows a lighter, almost playful side when dealing with his father's rigidness, contrasting with his coldness toward his wife.
Andrew shows a meticulous side in his military preparations, but his interactions with Mary reveal a deepening cynicism toward his marriage and a desire to test his sister's loyalty to their father.

She has transitioned from a petitioner for her son to a bold power-player within the Bezúkhov household.
Anna Mikháylovna has moved from social maneuvering to physical combat, showing a ruthless determination to secure Pierre's future.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna Schérer hosts a high-society reception in St. Petersburg.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pávlovna Schérer... greeting Prince Vasíli Kurágin, a man of high rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna expresses her intense hatred for Napoleon and her faith in Emperor Alexander.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that Antichrist—I really believe he is Antichrist—I will have nothing more to do with you

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives at the reception, causing social discomfort.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anna Pávlovna’s alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the aunt without waiting to hear her speech about Her Majesty’s health.

event_chronicle.description: Princess Bolkónskaya discusses her husband's departure for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “You know,” said the princess... “my husband is deserting me? He is going to get himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna gathers a group to hear the Vicomte de Mortemart's account of the Duc d’Enghien's death.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anna Pávlovna arranged a group round him, inviting everyone to listen to his tale.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced to the circle, displaying his lack of wit and awkward social presence.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: His face on the contrary was dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen self-confidence

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew Bolkónski announces he is going to war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: General Kutúzov... has been pleased to take me as an aide-de-camp....

event_chronicle.description: Princess Drubetskáya successfully pressures Prince Vasíli into promising to help her son Borís.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: But in Princess Drubetskáya’s case he felt, after her second appeal, something like qualms of conscience.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov publicly defends Napoleon's execution of the Duc d’Enghien as a political necessity.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “The execution of the Duc d’Enghien,” declared Monsieur Pierre, “was a political necessity, and it seems to me that Napoleon showed greatness of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole responsibility of that deed.”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna attempts to silence Pierre by inviting him to another table, which he ignores.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Won’t you come over to the other table?” suggested Anna Pávlovna. But Pierre continued his speech without heeding her.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna and Lise Bolkónskaya agree to pursue a marriage match between Anatole Kurágin and Andrew's sister.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I rely on you, my dear,” said Anna Pávlovna, also in a low tone. “Write to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter.”

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew and Pierre leave the soiree together to continue their conversation at Andrew's home.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I am expecting you, Pierre,” said the same voice, but gently and affectionately.

event_chronicle.description: Lise Bolkónskaya confronts Prince Andrew about his coldness and his decision to leave her for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Just for a whim of his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone in the country.”

event_chronicle.description: Lise reveals her pregnancy as a source of her fear, though she finds it 'indecorous' to speak of it directly before Pierre.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: She paused as if she felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the gist of the matter lay in that.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew delivers a cynical monologue advising Pierre never to marry, citing the loss of nobility and freedom.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Never, never marry, my dear fellow! That’s my advice: never marry till you can say to yourself that you have done all you are capable of”

event_chronicle.description: Pierre confesses his insecurity regarding his status as an illegitimate son without a name or means.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “What am I? An illegitimate son!” He suddenly blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a great effort to say this.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew warns Pierre to stop associating with the Kurágins and their lifestyle of debauchery.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “But look here: give up visiting those Kurágins and leading that sort of life. It suits you so badly—all this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!”

event_chronicle.description: Pierre breaks his promise to Prince Andrew by attending Anatole Kurágin's party.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: But he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go there. Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so passionately once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to that he decided to go.

event_chronicle.description: Dólokhov bets Stevens that he can drink a bottle of rum while sitting on a third-story window ledge.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anatole kept on refilling Pierre’s glass while explaining that Dólokhov was betting with Stevens, an English naval officer, that he would drink a bottle of rum sitting on the outer ledge of the third floor window.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre uses his physical strength to wrench an oak window frame out of the wall.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Pierre seized the crossbeam, tugged, and wrenched the oak frame out with a crash.

event_chronicle.description: Borís Drubetskóy is transferred to the Semënov Guards as a cornet through Prince Vasíli's influence.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an exception made, and Borís transferred into the regiment of Semënov Guards with the rank of cornet.

event_chronicle.description: The Rostóv family hosts a large name-day celebration in Moscow.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: It was St. Natalia’s day and the name day of two of the Rostóvs—the mother and the youngest daughter—both named Nataly.

event_chronicle.description: Moscow society gossips about Pierre Bezúkhov's expulsion from Petersburg and his father's illness.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The conversation was on the chief topic of the day: the illness of the wealthy and celebrated beau of Catherine’s day, Count Bezúkhov, and about his illegitimate son Pierre

event_chronicle.description: The younger Rostóv children and their friends burst into the drawing room, disrupting the formal visit.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: suddenly from the next room were heard the footsteps of boys and girls running to the door and the noise of a chair falling over

event_chronicle.description: Borís Drubetskóy follows Natásha out of the room after she runs away in a fit of laughter.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Borís quietly left the room and went in search of Natásha.

event_chronicle.description: Nicholas Rostóv publicly declares his vocation for the army, rejecting the idea that he is joining only for friendship with Borís.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “It’s not at all from friendship,” declared Nicholas, flaring up and turning away as if from a shameful aspersion. “It is not from friendship at all; I simply feel that the army is my vocation.”

event_chronicle.description: Sónya leaves the room in tears after witnessing Nicholas flirting with Julie Karágina.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: She gave him a passionately angry glance, and hardly able to restrain her tears and maintain the artificial smile on her lips, she got up and left the room.

event_chronicle.description: Nicholas and Sónya reconcile in the conservatory with a kiss, affirming their exclusive love for one another.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Well, then, I won’t; only forgive me, Sónya!” He drew her to him and kissed her.

event_chronicle.description: Natásha and Borís agree to marry in four years after Natásha impulsively kisses him.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Settled!” replied Borís. “Forever?” said the little girl. “Till death itself?”

event_chronicle.description: Véra interrupts the romantic pairings of Nicholas/Sónya and Borís/Natásha, causing a scene and driving them away.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: All four, like a flock of scared birds, got up and left the room.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Mikháylovna and the Countess discuss the Rostóvs' declining financial situation due to the Count's extravagance.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Don’t I know that at the rate we are living our means won’t last long? It’s all the Club and his easygoing nature.”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Mikháylovna and Borís arrive at the Bezúkhov house to visit the dying Count Cyril.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Countess Rostóva’s carriage in which they were seated drove over the straw covered street and turned into the wide courtyard of Count Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov’s house.

event_chronicle.description: The doctor Lorrain indicates that Count Bezúkhov's death is certain.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Prince, humanum est errare, * but...” replied the doctor, swallowing his r’s

event_chronicle.description: Prince Vasíli expresses contempt for Count Ilyá Rostóv.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I never could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that unlicked bear! A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a gambler too, I am told.”

event_chronicle.description: Pierre arrives at his father's house in Moscow and is shunned by his cousins.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Pierre was received as if he were a corpse or a leper.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Vasíli arrives in Moscow and forbids Pierre from seeing the dying Count.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The count is very, very ill, and you must not see him at all.

event_chronicle.description: Borís visits Pierre and invites him to dinner at the Rostóvs'.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Count Rostóv asks you to come to dinner today.

event_chronicle.description: Countess Rostóva requests and receives 700 rubles from Count Rostóv to assist Anna Mikháylovna.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Bring me...” he reflected a moment, “yes, bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don’t bring me such tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones for the countess.”

event_chronicle.description: The Countess gives the money to Anna Mikháylovna for Borís's military equipment.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “This is for Borís from me, for his outfit.” Anna Mikháylovna was already embracing her and weeping.

event_chronicle.description: The men gather in Count Rostóv's study to discuss the newly announced war manifesto and recruiting.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: In the count’s room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked of the war that had been announced in a manifesto, and about the recruiting.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives at the Rostóv house for the dinner party, maintaining his reputation for social awkwardness.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Pierre had come just at dinnertime and was sitting awkwardly in the middle of the drawing room

event_chronicle.description: The Colonel announces that the declaration of war has appeared in Petersburg and reached the commander in chief.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The colonel told them that the declaration of war had already appeared in Petersburg and that a copy... had that day been forwarded by courier to the commander in chief.

event_chronicle.description: Natásha Rostóva boldly interrupts the dinner to ask her mother about the dessert, causing a stir and eventual laughter among the guests.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?” and Natásha’s voice sounded still more firm and resolute.

event_chronicle.description: Nicholas Rostóv receives his military papers, confirming his departure for the war in one week.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Nicholas is going away in a week’s time, his... papers... have come... he told me himself...”

event_chronicle.description: Véra Rostóva discovers Sónya's private verses and threatens to expose her relationship with Nicholas to the Countess.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “she found them on my table and said she’d show them to Mamma, and that I was ungrateful, and that Mamma would never allow him to marry me”

event_chronicle.description: Count Bezúkhov suffers a sixth stroke and is pronounced beyond recovery by the doctors.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Count Bezúkhov had a sixth stroke. The doctors pronounced recovery impossible.

event_chronicle.description: The Military Governor of Moscow visits the Bezúkhov house to bid farewell to the Count.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The Military Governor of Moscow... came himself that evening to bid a last farewell to the celebrated grandee of Catherine’s court, Count Bezúkhov.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre and Anna Mikháylovna arrive at the Bezúkhov house via the back entrance to avoid notice.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: He noticed that they had not come to the front entrance but to the back door.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre and Anna Mikháylovna witness Prince Vasíli and the eldest princess in a secretive, agitated meeting.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: the princess jumped up and with a gesture of desperation slammed the door with all her might.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Mikháylovna presents Pierre to the religious officials at the Count's bedside, asserting his right to be there.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “God be thanked that you are in time,” said she to one of the priests; “all we relatives have been in such anxiety. This young man—”

event_chronicle.description: The religious service of extreme unction is performed for the dying Count Bezúkhov.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: By the chair stood the priests, their long hair falling over their magnificent glittering vestments, with lighted tapers in their hands, slowly and solemnly conducting the service.

event_chronicle.description: The Count is moved from his invalid chair to his bed as his condition remains critical.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: They had lifted the dying man and were moving him. ‘Catch hold of my arm or you’ll drop him!’ he heard one of the servants say in a frightened whisper.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Mikháylovna and the eldest princess engage in a physical struggle over a portfolio containing the Count's will.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Their efforts in the struggle for the portfolio were the only sounds audible, but it was evident that if the princess did speak, her words would not be flattering to Anna Mikháylovna.

event_chronicle.description: The second princess announces that Count Bezúkhov is dying, ending the physical struggle.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “What are you doing!” she cried vehemently. “He is dying and you leave me alone with him!”

event_chronicle.description: Prince Nicholas Bolkónski conducts a rigorous geometry lesson for Princess Mary.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: He took the exercise book containing lessons in geometry written by himself and drew up a chair with his foot.

event_chronicle.description: Princess Mary receives a letter from Julie Karágina, which the Prince threatens to read in the future.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I’ll let two more letters pass, but the third I’ll read,” said the prince sternly; “I’m afraid you write much nonsense. I’ll read the third!”

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew and Lise arrive at Bald Hills.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Prince Andrew got out of the carriage, helped his little wife to alight, and let her pass into the house before him.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew confirms his immediate departure for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “So you are really going to the war, Andrew?” she said sighing. ... “Yes, and even tomorrow,” replied her brother.

event_chronicle.description: The Bolkónski family dinner takes place, highlighting the rigid and eccentric atmosphere of Bald Hills.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: At the appointed hour the prince, powdered and shaven, entered the dining room where his daughter-in-law, Princess Mary, and Mademoiselle Bourienne were already awaiting him together with his architect.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew criticizes his father's vanity regarding the family's genealogical tree.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Everyone has his Achilles’ heel,” continued Prince Andrew. “Fancy, with his powerful mind, indulging in such nonsense!”

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew prepares his military equipment and luggage for his departure to the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Prince Andrew in a traveling coat without epaulettes had been packing with his valet in the rooms assigned to him.

event_chronicle.description: Princess Mary confronts Andrew about his cold treatment of Lise and their father's harsh character.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “To be quite frank, Mary, I expect Father’s character sometimes makes things trying for you, doesn’t it?” Prince Andrew asked suddenly.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER I
chapter_summaries.summary: In July 1805, Anna Pávlovna Schérer, a maid of honor to the Empress, hosts a reception in St. Petersburg. She greets Prince Vasíli Kurágin with a passionate political tirade against Napoleon (Buonaparte) and the state of European politics. They discuss the impending war, the role of Emperor Alexander, and the arrival of guests including the Vicomte de Mortemart and Abbé Morio.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER II
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna’s reception continues as more members of Petersburg high society arrive, including Prince Vasíli’s children, Hélène and Hippolyte, and the pregnant Princess Bolkónskaya. The social atmosphere is defined by rigid etiquette, specifically the mandatory greeting of Anna's aunt. Pierre Bezúkhov, the illegitimate son of a dying grandee, makes a socially awkward entrance, causing anxiety for the hostess due to his lack of conformity to courtly manners.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER III
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna organizes her guests into three distinct groups to facilitate conversation. The primary focus is on the Vicomte de Mortemart, whom Anna 'serves up' as a storyteller to discuss the murder of the Duc d’Enghien. Hélène Kurágina and Lise Bolkónskaya join this circle, while Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced as Hélène's physically similar but intellectually inferior brother.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew Bolkónski arrives at the soirée, displaying a weary and bored demeanor toward high society and his wife, Lise. He reveals he is departing for war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov. Pierre Bezúkhov shows great affection for Andrew, and they agree to meet for supper. Meanwhile, Prince Vasíli and Hélène depart, but not before Princess Drubetskáya entreats Vasíli to use his influence to secure a military appointment for her son, Borís.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER V
chapter_summaries.summary: The conversation at Anna Pávlovna's soirée turns to Napoleon's recent actions in Italy and the execution of the Duc d’Enghien. Pierre Bezúkhov shocks the aristocratic guests by defending Napoleon's actions as political necessities for the general good, while Prince Andrew supports Pierre's logic despite his own cynical outlook. The hostess, Anna Pávlovna, attempts to steer the conversation away from Pierre's controversial and socially inappropriate defense of the Revolution.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter_summaries.summary: As the soiree concludes, Pierre's social awkwardness is highlighted, though Anna Pávlovna offers him a mild, conditional forgiveness. Prince Hippolyte flirtatiously attends to Princess Lise, much to the indifference of Prince Andrew. Anna Pávlovna and Lise finalize a plan to match Anatole Kurágin with Andrew's sister. The chapter ends with Pierre and Andrew arriving at Andrew's home, where they begin a private discussion about Pierre's future and the political ideas discussed at the party.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew, Pierre, and Princess Lise Bolkónskaya converse in Andrew's study. Lise expresses her fear and resentment regarding Andrew's departure for the war, accusing him of being an egotist and changing toward her. The interaction reveals a deep marital strain, with Andrew treating her with cold, formal politeness while Pierre watches with awkward discomfort. The chapter ends with Lise's emotional outburst subsiding into a piteous submission before she retires for the night.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VIII
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew and Pierre have a private supper where Andrew reveals his deep disillusionment with marriage and high society. He warns Pierre never to marry, describing his own life as 'spoiled' and his wife as a burden to his freedom. Pierre, in turn, expresses his admiration for Andrew's strength of character and confesses his own uncertainty about his future as an illegitimate son.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER IX
chapter_summaries.summary: Pierre, despite his promise to Prince Andrew, attends a rowdy gathering at Anatole Kurágin's house. The party features heavy drinking and a dangerous bet involving Dólokhov drinking a bottle of rum on a window ledge. Pierre demonstrates his physical strength by wrenching out a window frame to facilitate the stunt.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER X
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Vasíli fulfills his promise to Princess Drubetskáya, securing Borís a transfer to the Guards. Anna Mikháylovna and Borís travel to Moscow to stay with their wealthy relatives, the Rostóvs. The chapter introduces the Rostóv household during a name-day celebration for the mother and youngest daughter, both named Nataly. The social atmosphere is busy with visitors discussing the failing health of Count Bezúkhov and the scandalous behavior of his son Pierre in Petersburg.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XI
chapter_summaries.summary: The formal atmosphere of the Rostóv drawing room is interrupted by the exuberant entrance of the younger generation, including Natásha, Nicholas, Sónya, and Pétya. Natásha, celebrating her name day, displays her childish charm and laughter, while the dynamics between the young adults—particularly Borís and Nicholas—are established through their contrasting social ease and physical descriptions.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XII
chapter_summaries.summary: The drawing room conversation continues with a focus on Nicholas Rostóv's decision to join the army. Nicholas expresses his passion for military service, while Sónya's romantic devotion to him is highlighted. A flirtatious interaction between Nicholas and Julie Karágina causes Sónya to leave the room in distress, prompting Nicholas to follow her. The elders, including the Count and Countess, discuss the upbringing of their children and Natásha's musical talent.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIII
chapter_summaries.summary: In the conservatory of the Rostóv house, Natásha hides and observes a tender reconciliation between Nicholas and Sónya, who reaffirm their love with a kiss. After they leave, Natásha lures Borís to her hiding spot, where she impulsively kisses him and secures a promise that he will ask for her hand in marriage in four years when she is sixteen.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIV
chapter_summaries.summary: Countess Rostóva and Princess Anna Mikháylovna have a private conversation about their financial struggles and social maneuvering. Meanwhile, the eldest daughter Véra interrupts the younger couples—Nicholas and Sónya, and Borís and Natásha—causing friction with her cold and critical demeanor. Anna Mikháylovna reveals how she used Prince Vasíli's influence to secure Borís's commission.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XV
chapter_summaries.summary: Princess Anna Mikháylovna and her son Borís visit the dying Count Cyril Bezúkhov in Moscow. While Borís feels humiliated by their poverty and his mother's sycophancy, Anna Mikháylovna persists in seeking favor from Prince Vasíli, who is managing the Count's affairs. They meet Prince Vasíli as he is dismissing the doctor, Lorrain, and Anna Mikháylovna attempts to secure her son's future by reminding the Prince of his obligations and the Count's role as Borís's godfather.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVI
chapter_summaries.summary: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives in Moscow after being expelled from Petersburg for his scandalous behavior. He is coldly received by his cousins, the princesses, at his dying father's house. Prince Vasíli arrives and forbids Pierre from seeing the count. Later, Borís Drubetskóy visits Pierre to invite him to dinner at the Rostóvs', leading to a conversation where Pierre's social clumsiness and political obsessions are contrasted with Borís's cool, observant nature.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVII
chapter_summaries.summary: Countess Rostóva, moved by Anna Mikháylovna's poverty, asks her husband for money. Despite their own financial decline, Count Rostóv provides seven hundred rubles. When Anna Mikháylovna returns from visiting the dying Count Bezúkhov, the Countess gives her the money for Borís's military outfit, leading to a tearful and affectionate exchange between the two lifelong friends.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVIII
chapter_summaries.summary: At the Rostóv house, guests await the arrival of the formidable Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova for dinner. In the Count's study, the men discuss the war manifesto while Shinshín ironically teases Lieutenant Berg about his self-centered financial ambitions and his transfer to the Guards. Pierre Bezúkhov arrives just as the guests prepare for dinner, appearing awkward in the drawing room.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIX
chapter_summaries.summary: During the Rostóv dinner, the men discuss the declaration of war against Napoleon. Nicholas Rostóv expresses intense patriotic fervor, supported by a German colonel and Pierre, while Shinshín remains skeptical. The chapter concludes with Natásha Rostóva's bold and mischievous interruption of the formal dinner to ask about the dessert, showcasing her spirited nature and her rapport with the guests.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XX
chapter_summaries.summary: Following the dinner, the guests disperse to various rooms for cards and music. Sónya, distressed by Nicholas's impending departure and Véra's spiteful comments about his potential marriage to Julie Karágina, hides away in tears. Natásha finds and comforts her, reassuring her of Nicholas's love and the possibility of their marriage despite being cousins. The young people then reunite to sing 'The Brook' for the guests.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXI
chapter_summaries.summary: As the Rostóvs' party continues elsewhere, Count Bezúkhov suffers a sixth stroke, and his death is imminent. The Military Governor of Moscow visits to pay his respects, while the household prepares for the sacrament of unction. Prince Vasíli, visibly anxious about the inheritance, seeks a private meeting with the eldest princess, Catiche, to discuss business matters as the family and doctors wait for the end.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXII
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Mikháylovna escorts a confused and passive Pierre to the dying Count Bezúkhov’s house. They enter through the back entrance, witnessing a house in chaotic preparation for the end. Along the way, they encounter Prince Vasíli and the eldest princess in a tense, secretive meeting. Anna Mikháylovna takes charge of Pierre, positioning herself as his protector and guide to ensure he sees his father and secures his interests before the end.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXIII
chapter_summaries.summary: The religious service for the dying Count Bezúkhov takes place in his bedroom, attended by his family, doctors, and priests. Pierre observes the solemn ritual while the youngest princess, Sophie, finds his awkwardness amusing. During the service, Prince Vasíli and the eldest princess, Catiche, conduct a secretive meeting behind the bed, and the chapter ends with the physical effort of moving the dying Count from his chair to his bed.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXIV
chapter_summaries.summary: In the aftermath of the religious service, the tension over Count Bezúkhov's inheritance reaches a breaking point. Anna Mikháylovna and the eldest princess, Catiche, engage in a physical struggle over an inlaid portfolio containing the Count's will. Prince Vasíli attempts to intervene but is largely ignored as the two women fight for control. The conflict is interrupted by the second princess, who announces that the Count is finally dying, allowing Anna Mikháylovna to seize the portfolio and rush into the bedroom.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXV
chapter_summaries.summary: The narrative shifts to Bald Hills, the estate of the retired General Prince Nicholas Bolkónski. The chapter establishes the rigid, disciplined routine of the household as they await the arrival of Prince Andrew and his pregnant wife. Prince Nicholas is depicted as a stern, exacting father who personally educates his daughter, Princess Mary, in mathematics to combat idleness and superstition. Mary, living in fear of her father's sharp temper, receives a letter from her friend Julie Karágina, which her father mockingly acknowledges before resuming a stressful geometry lesson.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXVI
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew and his pregnant wife, Lise, arrive at the Bolkónski estate, Bald Hills. They are greeted by the valet Tíkhon and later by Mademoiselle Bourienne and Princess Mary. The reunion is emotional for the women, who weep and embrace, while Prince Andrew remains detached and somewhat irritated by the display of emotion. Andrew confirms he is leaving for the war the following day, leaving Lise at the estate, which causes her further distress.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXVII
chapter_summaries.summary: The Bolkónski family gathers for dinner at Bald Hills. The old prince demonstrates his eccentric egalitarianism by seating his architect, Michael Ivánovich, at the table. Prince Andrew mocks his father's obsession with the family genealogy to Princess Mary, while the old prince subjects Lise to his dry, cold humor regarding her pregnancy. The conversation shifts to the war, where the old prince dismisses Napoleon as an insignificant 'Frenchy' and mocks modern military tactics, while Andrew respectfully engages his father's arguments about past generals like Suvórov.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XXVIII
chapter_summaries.summary: On the eve of his departure for war, Prince Andrew prepares his belongings and reflects on his future. He is interrupted by his sister, Princess Mary, who expresses her concern for his pregnant wife, Lise, and discusses their father's difficult temperament and religious views. Andrew remains cynical about his wife and their father's behavior, while Mary defends the old prince and shares her hopes for spiritual improvement.

book_summaries.summary: In July 1805, the St. Petersburg and Moscow aristocracies are preoccupied with the looming war against Napoleon and the impending death of the wealthy Count Bezúkhov. At Anna Pávlovna Schérer’s soirée, the socially awkward Pierre Bezúkhov and the disillusioned Prince Andrew Bolkónski emerge as central figures; Andrew decides to leave his pregnant wife, Lise, to serve as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov. Meanwhile, in Moscow, the vibrant Rostóv family celebrates a name day, highlighting the youthful romances of Natásha and Borís, and Nicholas and Sónya, before the young men depart for military service. The narrative arc is defined by the contrast between the rigid social maneuvering of Prince Vasíli and Anna Mikháylovna and the authentic, albeit chaotic, search for purpose by Pierre and Andrew. As Count Bezúkhov nears death, the struggle for his inheritance begins, while the younger generation is thrust from domestic stability into the uncertainty of the Napoleonic Wars.
